question: How many Mediterranean migrants and refugees will enter Europe in February 2025?
description: Al Jazeera: [EU leaders to discuss stricter measures to curb arrivals of asylum seekers](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/17/eu-leaders-to-discuss-stricter-measures-to-curb-arrivals-of-asylum-seekers) | CFR: [Europe’s Migration Dilemma](https://www.cfr.org/article/europes-migration-dilemma)
fine_print: Resolution will be from hovering over the relevant month in the "Sea and land arrivals from January 2016" chart.
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Bodies of migrants recovered in two locations in Libya, security...**
At least 29 bodies of migrants have been recovered in two locations in Libya, according to the Alwahat district Security Directorate and the Libyan Red Crescent. In the Jikharra area, 19 bodies were found in a mass grave, believed to be related to smuggling activities. The directorate stated, 'In the presence of the Public Prosecution Office in Jalu, the directorate was able to recover 19 bodies resulting from smuggling and illegal migration activities in Jikharra area, belonging to a known smuggling network.' Separately, the Libyan Red Crescent recovered 10 bodies after their boat sank off Dila port in Zawiya. The bodies were referred to a forensic doctor for necessary tests. Libya has become a transit route for migrants fleeing conflict and poverty to Europe across the Mediterranean.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 06, 2025 11:58 PM
Source:[Daily Mail Online](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-14370427/Bodies-migrants-recovered-two-locations-Libya-security-Red-Crescent-say.html)

**Morocco foils 78,685 migrant attempts to reach Europe in 2024**
Morocco has stopped 78,685 migrants from illegally crossing into European Union territory in 2024, a 4.6% increase from the previous year. According to the Interior Ministry, 58% of the migrants were from West Africa, 12% from North Africa, and 9% from East and Central Africa. The ministry cited 'growing migratory pressure in an unstable regional environment' as the reason for the increase. Morocco and Spain have strengthened cooperation against undocumented migration since 2022. Moroccan authorities rescued 18,645 would-be migrants from unseaworthy boats in 2024, a 10.8% increase from 2023. A migrant rights group reported that up to 50 migrants may have drowned in a recent deadly wreck involving people trying to make the Atlantic crossing from West Africa to Spain's Canary Islands.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 06, 2025 02:17 PM
Source:[The Straits Times](https://www.straitstimes.com/world/europe/morocco-foils-78685-migrant-attempts-to-reach-europe-in-2024)

**Morocco Intensifies Efforts Against Migrant Crossings into EU | Science-Environment**
In 2024, Morocco intercepted 78,685 migrants attempting to enter the EU illegally, a 4.6% increase from the previous year. The majority of migrants, 58%, came from West Africa, driven by conflict, unemployment, and climate change impacts. Morocco has increased cooperation with Spain to combat migration through the Mediterranean and Atlantic routes. The country's Interior Ministry reported that Moroccan authorities saved 18,645 migrants from unsafe vessels in 2024, a 10.8% increase from the previous year. However, tragedy struck last month when up to 50 migrants are believed to have drowned while attempting the perilous journey across the Atlantic to Spain's Canary Islands. 'The data underscores increasing migratory pressures within an unstable regional context,' the ministry stated in response to Reuters' inquiry.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 06, 2025 02:13 PM
Source:[Devdiscourse](https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/3255433-morocco-intensifies-efforts-against-migrant-crossings-into-eu)

**Remembering the Nameless: EU's Migration Policies Criticized**
The initiative 'Alarm Phone' reports on a daily basis about people in distress at sea. Between New Year's and the previous weekend, the UNHCR documented 12,137 people who arrived in Europe via the Mediterranean. Eight people died or went missing, and 2,824 people were counted as dead or missing at sea in 2024. The EU's border protection agency Frontex has been criticized for not using its funds to rescue people in distress. Instead, it informs the rescue centers in EU member states and in Libya and Tunisia when it detects boats with asylum seekers, refugees, and migrants. However, it does not inform non-state rescue boats, which can lead to people being intercepted and forcibly returned to Libya or Tunisia, where they are exposed to severe human rights violations. The EU has also made agreements with third countries, such as Turkey and Morocco, to return people to their countries of origin. The EU's reform of the Common European Asylum System, which will only grant a regular asylum procedure to those who do not come through a safe third country, is also criticized. 'Alarm Phone' calls for justice and remembers the victims of the EU's migration policies. 'We are committed to remembering those who have died or gone missing in their pursuit of freedom of movement, and to expressing our demands for justice,' the initiative says. Gedenkfeiern (memorial services) will take place in around 60 cities worldwide on Thursday. 'It is a principle that the EU gives money, and they 'take the people back' or prevent them from crossing the border,' says Human Rights Watch. The EU's policy has been criticized by many, including the former British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, who was stopped by the Supreme Court, and the Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, who is holding on to her Albanian model despite court decisions. CDU leader Friedrich Merz is also calling for border closures and a 'strengthening' of the right to asylum in Germany, effectively abolishing it.
Original language: de
Publish date: February 05, 2025 06:30 PM
Source:[jungewelt.de](https://www.jungewelt.de/artikel/493396.commemoraction-erinnerung-an-namenlose.html)

**African Migration to Europe and the Middle East Decreases, but Pressure Remains**
The number of African migrants attempting to cross into Europe and the Middle East has decreased significantly over the past year, according to recent data. In 2024, 146,000 African migrants were intercepted attempting to cross into Europe and the Middle East, a 52% decrease from the 282,000 cases recorded in 2023. This decline is attributed to increased efforts by the EU to prevent migration in North Africa (Libya, Tunisia, Morocco, and Egypt) and West Africa (Senegal and Mauritania). For example, Moroccan authorities report that they have prevented over 45,000 border crossings into Europe, arrested 177 human trafficking groups, and rescued over 10,800 people at sea in 2024. The number of African migrants attempting to cross into Yemen, a primary entry point into the Middle East, has decreased by 54% to 44,000, due to a combination of factors including the ongoing conflict in Yemen and a propaganda campaign against irregular migration through the Bab-el-Mandab Strait, led by the government of Djibouti. The number of African migrants who have died attempting to cross into Europe has decreased by 15% to 4,465, with 75% of these deaths occurring while attempting to cross the Mediterranean Sea and Atlantic Ocean. According to the UN, the number of African migrants (excluding refugees and asylum seekers) living in another African country has increased by 25% over the past 10 years, from 12 million in 2015 to 15 million in 2024. However, this number is likely underestimated, as much of internal migration in Africa is labor migration. A recent survey by the Afrobarometer found that nearly 50% of Africans are considering emigrating, a significant increase from 2016-2018. Given the projected 70% increase in Africa's population to 2.4 billion by 2050, it is likely that migration pressure on Europe and the Middle East will continue.
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 05, 2025 11:03 AM
Source:[bb.lv](https://bb.lv/statja/v-mire/2025/02/07/banka-po-cernomu-polovina-zitelei-afriki-gotova-bezat-v-es)

**Quarterly Mixed Migration Update: Europe Quarter 4 - 2024 - Cyprus**
The Quarterly Mixed Migration Update (QMMU) for Europe in Quarter 4 of 2024 highlights several key trends and developments. Notably, the total number of registered arrivals in Europe decreased to 199,200 in 2024, down from 270,700 in 2023, with the Central Mediterranean route experiencing a significant decline. However, the Eastern Mediterranean route to Greece saw a 27% increase, and the Western Africa / Atlantic route to the Canary Islands experienced a 16% rise. The update also reports on Cyprus granting entry to dozens of migrants trapped in the buffer zone, Greece and Cyprus facing condemnation from the European Court of Human Rights for pushbacks, and Italy's Albania migrant centre facing legal challenges. Furthermore, the update notes worsening humanitarian conditions in the Canary Islands, with calls for more central government support and the redistribution of underage migrants. Additionally, Spain has announced an ambitious regularisation programme for undocumented migrants, while Croatia has been accused of incinerating migrant belongings in 'burn piles'.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 05, 2025 10:30 AM
Source:[ReliefWeb](https://reliefweb.int/report/cyprus/quarterly-mixed-migration-update-europe-quarter-4-2024)

**Continua la crisi umanitaria nel Mediterraneo centrale, OIM: 'A gennaio più di duemila migranti intercettati e riportati in Libia'**
The Mediterranean central region continues to be the scene of one of the most severe humanitarian crises in recent years. According to the International Organization for Migration (OIM), at least 36 people died while attempting to cross the sea to reach Europe between January 1st and February 1st, 2025. Additionally, at least one person is missing. In the same period, over 2,000 people were intercepted at sea and brought back to Libya, 'only' 592 between January 26th and February 1st, 2025. The OIM report highlights the stories of people fleeing wars, persecutions, famines, and political instability, seeking a better life. The Mediterranean central route remains one of the most dangerous in the world, with overcrowded and often unsuitable boats challenging the open sea, leaving thousands of migrants, including women and children, often very young, at the mercy of the waves. The OIM report also notes that in the first month of the year, 2,398 people were intercepted at sea and brought back to Libya by local authorities. Among them, 1,984 men, 301 women, and 113 children. For many of them, returning to Libya means the nightmare of arbitrary detention, torture, and exploitation. Humanitarian organizations have been denouncing for years that Libyan detention centers are places of systematic violence, where migrants and refugees are victims of abuse, slavery, and human trafficking. The support of the European Union to the Libyan authorities, through funding and cooperation in border control, and that of Italy, through the so-called Memorandum of Understanding, raises serious questions about the responsibility of European institutions in these ongoing human rights violations. The Memorandum of Understanding between Italy and Libya, signed on February 2nd, 2017, is an agreement aimed at blocking migrant departures to Italy through the strengthening of cooperation with Libyan authorities, of which also Marco Minniti, then Minister of the Interior, was a great supporter. Financed with hundreds of millions of euros by Italy and the European Union, the Memorandum has provided the supply of patrol boats and logistical support to the so-called Libyan Coast Guard, composed mainly of militias with direct links to human trafficking. The agreement has led to the systematic interception and capture of migrants at sea, with their subsequent transfer to Libyan detention centers, real lagers where, according to numerous reports by the United Nations and international NGOs, crimes against humanity are perpetrated: torture, rape, slavery, and murder. Despite repeated denunciations and concrete evidence of the involvement of Libyan militia leaders in human trafficking, including the well-known Libyan general accused of war crimes and crimes against humanity, Osama Njeem Almasri, or Abdul Rahman al-Milad, known as 'Bija', present at an official meeting at the Viminale in 2017, the Memorandum has been renewed several times, with the support of various Italian governments. The operations of repulsion conducted in collaboration with Libya have been denounced to the International Criminal Court for violation of international norms on human rights, while the same International Criminal Court has confirmed that the crimes committed in Libyan detention centers are configured as war crimes and crimes against humanity. Despite numerous denunciations and reports from humanitarian organizations, the international community's response seems inadequate. Access to humanitarian aid for asylum seekers is limited, funds for migrant protection are insufficient, and safe corridors seem almost non-existent. The United Nations and NGOs have been asking for years for urgent interventions to address the root causes of forced migration, such as conflicts, inequalities, climate change, and persecutions. Parallelly, they call for the creation of legal pathways for refugees and migrants, in order to reduce human trafficking and the number of victims along migration routes.
Original language: it
Publish date: February 05, 2025 10:09 AM
Source:[Fanpage](https://www.fanpage.it/politica/continua-la-crisi-umanitaria-nel-mediterraneo-centrale-oim-a-gennaio-piu-di-duemila-migranti-intercettati-e-riportati-in-libia/)

**At Least 36 Migrants Dead, 1 Missing in Central Mediterranean in 2025**
According to the International Organization for Migration (OIM), at least 36 people have lost their lives in the central Mediterranean route from the beginning of the year to February 1st. In the same period, the OIM reported that 2,398 migrants were intercepted at sea and returned to Libya, consisting of 1,984 men, 301 women, and 113 minors. The OIM stated that this situation is a cause for concern, highlighting the need for increased efforts to protect migrants and prevent such tragedies from occurring.
Original language: it
Publish date: February 05, 2025 06:25 AM
Source:[interris.it](https://www.interris.it/esteri/oim-36-vittime-e-un-disperso-nel-mediterraneo-centrale-nel-2025/)

**36 Migrants Dead, 1 Missing in Central Mediterranean in 2025**
According to the International Organization for Migration (IOM) in Libya, at least 36 people have died and one is missing in the central Mediterranean route from the beginning of the year to February 1st. The IOM reported that 2,398 migrants were intercepted at sea and brought back to Libya during the same period, consisting of 1,984 men, 301 women, and 113 minors. The IOM stated that these numbers are a 'concerning trend' and that the situation in the Mediterranean remains 'highly complex and volatile'.
Original language: it
Publish date: February 05, 2025 06:06 AM
Source:[ANSA.it](https://www.ansa.it/sito/notizie/topnews/2025/02/05/oim-36-morti-e-un-disperso-nel-mediterraneo-centrale-nel-2025_96985d33-757e-496b-a40e-d0c4f04f4c21.html)

**592 migrants intercepted off Libyan coast over past week: IOM**
The International Organization for Migration (IOM) reported that 592 migrants, including 64 women and 33 children, were intercepted and returned to Libya between January 26 and February 1. IOM stated that seven migrants went missing and 21 bodies were retrieved off the Libyan coast. So far this year, 2,398 migrants have been intercepted and returned to Libya, while 36 have died on the Central Mediterranean route. In 2024, 21,762 migrants were rescued and returned to Libya, with 674 deaths and 1,015 missing on the route. IOM noted that since the fall of Muammar Gaddafi in 2011, many migrants have chosen to cross the Mediterranean Sea to European shores from Libya.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 05, 2025 01:11 AM
Source:[dailyfinland.fi](https://www.dailyfinland.fi/worldwide/41651/592-migrants-intercepted-off-Libyan-coast-over-past-week-IOM)

**SEM predicts a decrease in asylum requests for 2025**
The Swiss State Secretariat for Migration (SEM) predicts a decrease of 15% in new asylum requests for the current year, with 24,000 expected applications (-4,000 compared to 2024). This is the most likely scenario, according to a note released today. A second scenario (with a probability of occurrence of 25-35%) estimates 32,000 (+/- 5,000) requests, while a third (10-15%) predicts 20,000 (+/- 2,000). The actual number of requests will depend on how many people emigrate from Turkey to Greece and Bulgaria and then migrate to central and western Europe. The evolution of migration movements from North Africa to Italy via the Mediterranean is also crucial, as highlighted in the statement. Last year, 27,740 asylum requests were submitted in Switzerland, a decrease of 2,483 compared to 30,223 in 2023 (-8% approximately). Of these, 6,521 were secondary requests (e.g. births, family reunifications or multiple asylum requests). Approximately 3,300 secondary requests were submitted by people from Afghanistan who had already been residing in the Confederation for some time and submitted another request.
Original language: it
Publish date: January 31, 2025 08:40 AM
Source:[www.Bluewin.ch](https://www.bluewin.ch/it/attualita/svizzera/asilo-previste-meno-richieste-nel-2025-2542454.html)

**Irregular Entries in Europe Decrease by 38% in 2024, But New Routes Emerge**
According to Frontex, the number of irregular entries in Europe has decreased by 38% in 2024 compared to 2023, reaching its lowest level since 2021. In 2024, 239,000 people, including 10% of women and 16% of minors, attempted to enter Europe irregularly, down from 380,000 in 2023. The decline is mainly seen on the 'Mediterranean Central' and 'Balkans' routes, which are the most used migration routes. However, despite the efforts of the European Union and transit countries to combat smugglers and block irregular entries, migrants are adapting and exploring new routes, making their journeys even more perilous. The number of attempts to enter Europe via the Canary Islands has increased by 18%, with nearly 47,000 refugees arriving in Spain and overwhelming the archipelago's reception capacities. The number of attempts via the eastern Mediterranean (Greece, Cyprus) has also increased by 14% in 2024. The number of attempts via the eastern borders has increased by 192%, with 17,000 people crossing the borders of Poland, Lithuania, or Finland via Russia and Belarus. These two countries are accused of 'instrumentalizing migrants' by providing them with equipment to cross the EU's borders. The European Commission has granted Poland the right to temporarily derogate from the asylum law to address this issue.
Original language: fr
Publish date: January 16, 2025 01:05 PM
Source:[Le Monde.fr](https://www.lemonde.fr/international/article/2025/01/16/avec-38-de-baisse-le-nombre-d-entrees-irregulieres-en-europe-enregistre-son-niveau-le-plus-bas-depuis-2021_6501301_3210.html)

**Mediterranean claimed more than 2,200 migrant lives in 2024. Here’s why it could be worse this year**
More than 2,200 people died or disappeared trying to cross the Mediterranean Sea in 2024, according to the United Nations. Experts warn that the number could be even higher in 2025 without real change. The deaths come after a year of increasing crackdowns on civilian rescue boats and an attempt by Italy's far-right government to pass asylum-seekers off to Albania. Michael Gordon, a research fellow at the Balsillie School of International Affairs, said that the 'criminalization' of search-and-rescue operations has led to fewer assets assisting migrants in distress, resulting in more deaths. Regina De Dominicis, UNICEF's regional director for Europe and Central Asia, stated that 'hundreds of children' have died in the Mediterranean, who are fleeing violent conflict and poverty. The EU has focused on origin countries for migrant control, delivering millions of euros in aid to Tunisia and Egypt, but human rights groups have stated that returning migrants found at sea to Libya exposes them to torture and abuse. Experts say that without meaningful change, tragedies in the Mediterranean will continue.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 08, 2025 02:08 PM
Source:[atinitonews.com](https://www.atinitonews.com/2025/01/mediterranean-claimed-more-than-2200-migrant-lives-in-2024-heres-why-it-could-be-worse-this-year/)

**Mediterranean claimed more than 2,200 migrant lives in 2024. Here's why it could be worse this year | CBC News**
More than 2,200 people died or disappeared trying to cross the Mediterranean Sea in 2024, according to the United Nations. Experts warn that the number could be higher in 2025 without real change. The deaths come after a year of increasing crackdowns on civilian rescue boats in the Mediterranean and an attempt by Italy's far-right government to pass asylum-seekers off to Albania. Michael Gordon, a research fellow at the Balsillie School of International Affairs, said that the criminalization of search-and-rescue operations has led to fewer assets assisting migrants in distress, resulting in more deaths. Regina De Dominicis, UNICEF's regional director for Europe and Central Asia, said that hundreds of children make up one in five of all people migrating through the Mediterranean, fleeing violent conflict and poverty. Growing anti-immigration sentiment is making these crossings more dangerous, according to experts and human rights groups. 'The fact that we have fewer arrivals does not mean that we have fewer risks,' Nicola Dell'Arciprete, country co-ordinator of UNICEF's migration and refugee response in Italy, said. Dell'Arciprete added that minimizing migrant deaths requires more investment in reception centres, contingency plans for high-arrival periods, more safe and legal pathways for immigration and strengthened search-and-rescue operations. 'Until we strengthen the search-and-rescue operations, until we create safe and legal pathways for children to travel to Europe, we are going to see more people dying,' Dell'Arciprete said. 'And that is a simple fact.'
Original language: en
Publish date: January 08, 2025 09:03 AM
Source:[CBC News](https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/mediterranean-migrants-death-2024-1.7424467)

**Over 2,000 refugees, migrants die reaching Europe in 2024, says UN - MyJoyOnline**
According to the United Nations and Italian sources, over 2,000 refugees have died in 2024 while attempting to reach Europe. The United Nations International Children's Fund (UNICEF) reported at least 2,200 deaths or missing refugees and migrants in the Mediterranean Sea. Regina De Dominicis, director of UNICEF's Regional Office for Europe and Central Asia, emphasized that many victims were young people and urged governments to prioritize the protection of children seeking safety in Europe. The UNHCR reported 193,448 arrivals in Europe by December 29, with Italy being the primary landing point for refugees and migrants.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 07, 2025 05:58 AM
Source:[MyJoyOnline.com](https://www.myjoyonline.com/over-2000-refugees-migrants-die-reaching-europe-in-2024-says-un/)

**Over 2,200 Migrants Dead in Mediterranean in 2024**
According to Regina De Dominicis, Director of the UNICEF Regional Office for Europe and Central Asia, more than 2,200 migrants have died in the Mediterranean in 2024, with nearly 1,700 lives lost on the central Mediterranean route. 'One in five migrants is a minor, fleeing from violent conflicts and poverty', De Dominicis said. The UNICEF is calling on governments to use the Migration and Asylum Pact to prioritize the protection of children, including safe and legal pathways for protection and family reunification, coordinated search and rescue operations, safe landings, community-based reception, and access to asylum services. The organization is also urging increased investments in essential services for children and families arriving through dangerous migration routes, such as psychological support, legal assistance, healthcare, and education. 'Governments must address the root causes of migration and support the integration of families into host communities, ensuring that children's rights are protected throughout their journey',
Original language: it
Publish date: January 06, 2025 03:00 PM
Source:[borderline24.com](https://www.borderline24.com/2025/01/06/oltre-2200-migranti-morti-nel-2024-nel-mediterraneo/)

**UNICEF: Mediterranean Sea Sees Tragic Loss of Life, Including Hundreds of Children**
According to UNICEF, more than 2,200 people have died in the Mediterranean Sea in 2024, including 112 children. However, the actual number of deaths is believed to be much higher. 'Among these are hundreds of girls, boys, and adolescents,' said Regina De Dominicis, Director of the UNICEF Regional Office for Europe and Central Asia and Special Coordinator for the Response to Refugees and Migrants in Europe. 'One in five migrants crossing the Mediterranean is a minor, most of whom are fleeing violent conflicts and poverty,' she added. UNICEF is calling on governments to use the Global Compact for Migration and Refugees to prioritize the protection of children and ensure safe and legal pathways for them. This includes coordinated search and rescue operations, safe landings, community-based reception, and access to asylum services. The organization is also urging increased investment in essential services for children and families arriving through perilous migration routes, such as psychological support, legal assistance, healthcare, and education. 'Hundreds of people have died in recent days,' said Alarm Phone. 'When will it end?' 
Original language: it
Publish date: January 03, 2025 10:12 AM
Source:[avvenire.it](https://www.avvenire.it/attualita/pagine/migranti-la-strage-dei-bambini-in-mare)

**Migrant Deaths in Europe Rise in 2024**
According to the United Nations, over 2,000 migrants have lost their lives while attempting to reach Europe in 2024. The United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) reported that at least 2,200 migrants and refugees died or went missing in the Mediterranean last year. UNICEF Director for Europe and Central Asia, Regina de Dominicis, stated that 'most of the victims were young people' and urged governments to prioritize the protection of children seeking safety in Europe. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) reported that 2,368 people lost their lives or went missing on the Mediterranean and North African routes in 2024. As of December 29, 193,448 people have reached Europe, with Italy being the primary point of entry for migrants and refugees, followed by Greece and Spain.

**Migrant Deaths in the Mediterranean Increase Despite Decrease in Arrivals**
The number of migrants arriving in Europe has decreased in 2024, but the mortality rate has increased. According to the Missing Migrants project, 2,279 people died in the Mediterranean in 2024, a 27% decrease from the previous year. However, the mortality rate has increased, and the number of people fleeing wars, conflicts, and environmental disasters has reached a record high for the second consecutive year. Regina De Dominicis, Unicef's Coordinator for Refugee and Migrant Response in Europe, notes that many people are fleeing these situations. The European Union's new asylum pact, set to take effect in 2026, will further restrict the rights of refugees. The number of people arriving in Europe via the Atlantic route has increased by 19%, with the Canary Islands receiving a record number of arrivals. The Atlantic route is considered the most deadly, with over 6,829 people having died in the stretch of sea between the west coast of Africa and the Canary Islands, according to a report by Caminando Fronteras. 'It is a shame that the right to asylum is being restricted for people who are fleeing wars, conflicts, and environmental disasters,' said Regina De Dominicis. 'The number of people who are dying in the Mediterranean is a testament to the need for a more humane and effective migration policy.'
Original language: it
Publish date: January 03, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[nigrizia.it](https://www.nigrizia.it/notizia/migrazioni-nel-2024-meno-arrivi-ma-piu-morti)

**Unicef: Over 2,200 Lives Lost in Mediterranean in 2024**
According to Unicef, over 2,200 people have lost their lives or gone missing in the Mediterranean in 2024, with nearly 1,700 of those deaths occurring on the central Mediterranean route. 'Hundreds of girls, boys, and adolescents are among the victims', said Regina De Dominicis, Unicef Regional Director for Europe and Central Asia and Special Coordinator for the European Refugee and Migrant Response. De Dominicis emphasized that 'one in five migrants crossing the Mediterranean is a minor, fleeing violent conflicts and poverty'. The Unicef is calling on governments to prioritize the protection of children through the Global Compact on Migration and Refugees, ensuring safe and legal pathways for protection and family reunification, coordinated search and rescue operations, safe landings, community-based reception, and access to asylum services. The organization is also urging increased investments in essential services for children and families arriving through perilous migration routes, including psychological support, legal assistance, healthcare, and education. Governments must address the root causes of migration and support the integration of families into host communities, ensuring that children's rights are protected throughout their journey.
Original language: it
Publish date: January 02, 2025 08:45 AM
Source:[ANSA.it](https://www.ansa.it/sito/notizie/mondo/africa/2025/01/02/unicef-2.200-morti-e-dispersi-nel-mediterraneo-nel-2024_1d22e37f-35eb-4795-8fba-3c3edf8f10ce.html)

**Unicef Reports Over 2,200 Mediterranean Deaths and Disappearances in 2024**
According to Regina De Dominicis, Director of the Unicef Regional Office for Europe and Central Asia, over 2,200 people have lost their lives or gone missing in the Mediterranean in 2024, with nearly 1,700 of those deaths occurring on the central Mediterranean route. 'Hundreds of girls, boys, and adolescents are among the victims', she said. De Dominicis emphasized that 'one in five migrants is a minor, fleeing violent conflicts and poverty'. The Unicef is calling on governments to prioritize the protection of children through the Global Compact for Migration and Refugees, ensuring safe and legal pathways for protection and family reunification, coordinated search and rescue operations, safe disembarkation, community-based reception, and access to asylum services. The organization is also urging increased investments in essential services for children and families arriving through perilous migration routes, including psychosocial support, legal assistance, healthcare, and education. Governments must address the root causes of migration and support the integration of families into host communities, ensuring that children's rights are protected throughout their journey.
